Project Number: 46221-001 
Regional–Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
May 2012 
 
 
 
 
Enhancing Engagement with Pacific Developing 
Member Countries, Phase 2 
(Financed by the Government of Australia) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Pacific Approach 2010–2014 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) identifies the 
need to promote more effective development processes.1 Considerable efforts have been made 
by Pacific governments and development partners alike to enhance development effectiveness 
in the Pacific, and are reflected in endorsement of the Paris Declaration on Aid Effectiveness 
and the Cairns Compact on Strengthening Development Coordination in the Pacific. However, 
the fragile characteristics exhibited by most Pacific developing member countries (DMCs) make 
ongoing efforts towards improved development effectiveness essential.  
 
2.  In  facilitating  enhanced  development  effectiveness,  ADB  and  the World  Bank  have 
supported  the  operation  of  development  coordination  offices  (DCOs) 2 in  Kiribati,  Samoa, 
Solomon Islands, Tonga, and Vanuatu.3 Each DCO is occupied by a country focal officer with 
the support of an administrative assistant. The support provided, through the DCOs, to the 
implementation of national development strategies and to coordinated policy dialogue between 
development partners and governments has resulted in requests for the DCOs’ continuance 
where  they  are  already  in  operation  and  their  replication  in  additional  Pacific  DMCs.  The 
proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  continue  to  improve  coordination  of  ADB  and 
development partner assistance to each of the Pacific DMCs participating in the TA, thus 
contributing to improved development effectiveness.  
 
3.  ADB’s discussions with the governments of the Cook Islands, Kiribati, the Federated 
States of Micronesia (FSM), Solomon Islands, and Vanuatu have resulted in an understanding 
of  the  impact,  outcomes,  and  outputs  of  the  TA,  as  well  as  its  costs,  implementation 
arrangements, cofinancing arrangements, and the terms of reference for consulting services. 
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Communities in Pacific DMCs are frequently widely dispersed and isolated and often 
retain strong historical family, village, island, language, and/or ethnic allegiances. This has 
made the building of understanding, ownership, and commitment by their peoples to national 
development goals and the concept of decision making based on the general public or national 
interest an ongoing process. Pacific DMCs and their development partners are making efforts to 
strengthen governance in the region. For assistance programs to be most effective in this 
development  environment,  experience  has  shown  development  partners  require  a  close, 
sensitive,  and  direct  presence  in  the  Pacific  DMCs.  This  allows  for  in-depth,  in-country 
coordination and policy dialogue between governments and their development partners.  
 
5.  Reflecting ADB’s endorsement of the Paris Declaration on Aid Effectiveness and the 
Cairns Compact on Strengthening Development Coordination in the Pacific, ADB is working 
closely  with  Pacific  DMCs  and  development  partners  to  improve  coordination,  promote 
harmonization of ADB and development partner assistance, and to produce better results from 
its efforts to reduce poverty and promote development. The combination of geographic isolation 
of the Pacific DMCs and the relatively small scale ADB programs in these countries requires 
creative and innovative approaches to ensure that ADB’s response to country development

priorities is appropriate and cost-effective, and delivers results. In response to the particular 
challenges for project implementation posed by the geographical isolation; weak core state 
functions and service delivery capacity; and weak social, political, and security systems of some 
Pacific DMCs, ADB supports strong coordination with Pacific DMCs and development partners 
to enhance the impact and efficiency of development assistance.  
 
6.  Successful implementation of the previous TA was expected to raise demand for similar 
support in other Pacific DMCs. Feedback from the governments and development partners 
confirmed  the  DCOs  initiated  under  the  previous  TA  had  enhanced  engagement  with  the 
participating Pacific DMCs, including by: 
(i)  strengthening  ADB’s  relations  with  the  governments,  private  sector  and  civil 
society organizations; 
(ii)  improving government coordination of aid;  
(iii)  facilitating greater harmonization of aid by ADB and other development partners; 
(iv)  improving information sharing, policy dialogue, and joint analytical work with the 
governments and development partners; 
(v)  improving the performance of ADB’s portfolio; and 
(vi)  strengthening the relationship between ADB and the World Bank. 
 
7.  However, experiences with the previous TA demonstrated that attention needed to be 
paid to: (i) managing the expectations of some Pacific DMC governments and development 
partners with regard to the role and decision-making authority of the country focal officers, (ii) 
selecting  country  focal  officers  who  have  the  appropriate  skills  and  attitude,  (iii)  carefully 
managing the scheduling of development partner missions to ensure that country focal officers 
are available to fully participate as required, and (iv) ensuring the reporting lines between the 
DCOs, the governments, and ADB’s Pacific Subregional Office (SPSO), Pacific Liaison and 
Coordination Office (PLCO), and Pacific Department (PARD) headquarters are clear. 
 
8.  The governments of Solomon Islands and Vanuatu support the continuation of their 
DCOs. One of the criteria warranting initial establishment of the DCOs was the size of current, 
and  likely  future,  ADB  country  portfolios  in  each  of  the  Pacific  DMCs.5 In  2011,  Vanuatu 
resumed borrowing from ADB after a period of 12 years. Two loans programmed for 2013 will 
introduce  a  strong  focus  on  urban  development  and  renewable  energy.    Continuation  of 
Vanuatu’s DCO will enable ADB to support engagement around this strengthened portfolio. The 
scope of ADB-supported activities in Solomon Islands continues to deepen, and with borrowing 
expected  to  resume  during  2012,  this  trend  is  anticipated  to  continue.  Furthermore, 
considerable infrastructure investment is being made by the Government of Solomon Islands, 
including with the support of development partners, with ADB focusing on road and water 
transport. The addition of an infrastructure specialist to Solomon Islands’ DCO would support 
the building of government’s capacity to implement and administer a growing infrastructure 
portfolio.6 The  Government  of  Solomon  Islands  has  demonstrated  itself  receptive  to  such 
support; the  DCO  in  Solomon  Islands  has, for  example,  provided  valuable  support  to the 
functioning of the joint government-development partner core economic working group. 
 
9.  The governments of the Cook Islands and FSM have asked ADB to establish DCOs in 
their countries. Both countries are expected to continue to have a strong relationship with ADB 
with a significant assistance pipeline, by Pacific standards, covering areas such as infrastructure

planning  and  services, water  supply,  renewable  energy  and  energy  policy,  public financial 
management,  and  public  sector reforms.  Enhanced  policy  dialogue  will  support  successful 
implementation of projects, and DCOs could facilitate the governments in their coordination of 
policy dialogue with all development partners. Both countries have clear capacity constraints in 
the public sector. The additional human resources the DCOs could bring to the area of aid 
coordination are expected to make a difference in governments’ ability to lead dialogue.  
 
10.  ADB support for an administrative assistant in the World Bank-funded DCO-equivalent in 
Kiribati,  which  is  shared  with  ADB,  will  enable  additional  support  to  the  government  and 
strengthen both banks’ collaboration in that country. ADB’s project level engagement in Kiribati 
has increased considerably - two loans were approved in 2010 and 2011 after Kiribati had taken 
no loans for 12 years. ADB is active in public financial management, state-owned enterprise 
reform, water supply and sanitation, and road transport. This heightened engagement is placing 
additional  coordination  demands  on  government  and  increased  resourcing  of  the  DCO-
equivalent in Kiribati would facilitate a stronger government lead in aid coordination and policy 
dialogue.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The impact of the TA in each of the five participating Pacific DMCs will be enhanced 
implementation of national plans. The outcome will be improved ADB portfolio management and 
aid coordination in each of the participating Pacific DMCs.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA proposes to (i) continue the existing DCOs in Solomon Islands and Vanuatu, (ii) 
establish  new  DCOs  in  the  Cook  Islands  and  FSM,  (iii)  contribute  the  resource  of  an 
administrative assistant to the World Bank’s DCO-equivalent in Kiribati, and (iv) recruit an 
infrastructure specialist to the DCO in Solomon Islands. 
 
13.  The outputs will comprise (i) DCO support for governments in implementation of national 
plans and aid coordination, and (ii) high quality advice on infrastructure project design and 
implementation in Solomon Islands (and in Nauru and Vanuatu, subject to available capacity). 
The  facilitating  role  of DCOs  (e.g.,  information  sharing,  capacity  building,  and  sourcing  of 
advice) and the technical expertise of the infrastructure specialist will enhance ADB portfolio 
management and improve the capacity of governments to lead efforts in aid coordination.  
 
14.  The previous TA established DCOs in Solomon Islands (2008), Tonga (2009), and 
Vanuatu (2010) to enhance engagement with ADB’s Pacific DMCs. A DCO comprises a country 
focal officer, an administrative assistant, and office facilities. In Solomon Islands, ADB and the 
World Bank fund a joint DCO, but employ separate country focal officers. The World Bank 
shares its DCO-equivalents in Kiribati and Samoa with ADB, while the services of the DCOs in 
Tonga  and  Vanuatu  are  shared  with  the  World  Bank.  Further  grant  cofinancing  from  the 
Government of Australia for one transport specialist (operating from ADB’s Papua New Guinea 
Resident Mission), and an environment and climate change specialist (operating from SPSO), 
enabled the provision of expert advice and support on specific sector issues important to the 
objectives of the previous TA.  
 
15.  The country focal officers, infrastructure specialist, and the administrative assistants will

4   
be contracted under the TA for 2 years from 1 July 2012. Each of these positions will be 
provided with (i) business premises, (ii) office furniture, equipment, and supplies, and (iii) an 
agreed budget, work program, and reporting arrangements. Midterm and final TA reviews, 
including assessment of the effectiveness of the consultant roles, should be completed 1 and 2 
years, respectively, after the country focal officers and infrastructure specialist  are fielded. 
These  reviews  should  be  conducted  jointly  with  the  Australian  Agency  for  International 
Development (AusAID) and the World Bank.  
 
16.  ADB will promote cost-effective and efficient implementation of the TA by (i) closely 
coordinating and collaborating with the World Bank Sydney office and its DCO-equivalents in 
Kiribati, Samoa, and Solomon Islands, and (ii) drawing on the pool of skilled persons in each of 
the Pacific DMCs covered by the TA to provide the required consultants. These mechanisms 
will allow ADB to give better service to the selected Pacific DMCs. The World Bank has limited 
operations in FSM; however, ADB will explore opportunities for the World Bank to supplement 
this office. The Cook Islands is not a World Bank member and as such there is no potential for 
collaboration in this DCO.  
 
17.  Drawing on the lessons of the previous TA, during the implementation of the TA, PARD 
officers will reinforce with governments and development partners the role and decision-making 
authority  of  the  country  focal  officers.  The  country  focal  officers  will  engage  development 
partners early to ensure that missions are scheduled appropriately. To ensure the reporting 
lines between the DCOs, the governments, and ADB’s SPSO, PLCO, and PARD headquarters 
are clear, terms of reference for the country focal officers will establish appropriate reporting 
responsibilities. Attention will be paid to recruiting consultants with a good understanding of 
development in their respective countries, as well as an appropriate attitude.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $2,016,000. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Government of Australia and administered by ADB. AusAID has approved the 
grant. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  ADB will be the executing agency for this TA and implementation responsibilities will rest 
with PARD. Once logistical arrangements to support the enhanced engagement activities have 
been made, day-to-day communications and reporting will be through SPSO in the case of the 
Cook Islands and Kiribati DCOs; through the Pacific Urban, Social Development and Public 
Management Division, PARD for the FSM DCO; and through PLCO for Solomon Islands and 
Vanuatu DCOs. PARD will closely monitor the introduction and implementation of the new 
DCOs in the Cook Islands, Kiribati, and FSM. Cross-learning between the established DCOs in 
Solomon Islands, Tonga, and Vanuatu and the new offices will be facilitated through monitoring 
and mentoring by senior ADB staff. 
 
20.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 24 months from 1 July 2012 to 30 June 
2014. Implementation will require 240 person-months of consultant services (48 person-months 
of  international  and  192  person-months  of  national),  comprising  (i)  24  person-months  of

5 
international consulting services for the country focal officer in Solomon Islands7, (ii) 24 person-
months of international consulting services for the infrastructure specialist in Solomon Islands, 
(iii) 72 person-months of national consulting services for country focal officers in the Cook 
Islands, FSM, and Vanuatu, and (iv) 120 person-months of national consulting services for 
administrative assistants in the five DCOs. The successful applicants for these positions will be 
recruited  as  individual  consultants  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The terms of reference for consultants are in 
Appendix 3. 
 
21.  The  procurement  of  office  equipment  financed  under  the  TA  will  follow  ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). The equipment will be handed 
over to the official contact points of the host governments on TA completion.  
 
22.  The  proceeds  of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
23.  Each country focal officer will prepare an inception report within 4 weeks of the start of 
field activities, including a work program with milestones and performance measures that will 
have been agreed upon by the relevant ADB country or regional director and the respective 
government. ADB will provide the work plans to AusAID for its information. Each country focal 
officer  will  provide  quarterly  DCO  performance  reports  to  ADB  and  to  the  respective 
government. ADB will report on TA progress during portfolio discussions between ADB and 
AusAID every 6 months. 
 
24.  The TA will be monitored through regular ADB missions. A midterm review of the TA will 
commence by June 2013. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
 
25.  The  President  recommends  that  the  Board  approve  ADB  administering  technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,016,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the 
Government of Australia for Enhancing Engagement with Pacific Developing Member Countries, 
Phase 2. 
                                                
7 Because  suitable  national  candidates  were  not  available  in  Solomon  Islands  under  the  previous  TA,  an   
international consultant may have to be recruited to fill the post of country focal officer in Solomon Islands under 
the TA. A similar approach may be needed in other Pacific DMCs if suitable national candidates were not available.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Consulting services will support the implementation of the technical assistance (TA) for 
Enhancing Engagement with Pacific Developing Member Countries, Phase 2. The consultants 
will comprise four country focal officers—one in each of the Cook Islands, Federated States of 
Micronesia (FSM), Solomon Islands, and Vanuatu; five administrative assistants—one in each 
of the Cook Islands, Kiribati, the FSM, Solomon Islands, and Vanuatu; and an infrastructure 
specialist in Solomon Islands. 
 
A.  Country Focal Officers: Cook Islands (national, 24 person-months); the FSM (national, 
24  person-months);  Solomon  Islands  (international,  24  person-months);  Vanuatu 
(national, 24 person-months) 
 
2.  The country focal officers will be responsible for supporting the respective governments 
in implementing their national development strategies and facilitating strengthened coordination 
between the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the governments, as well as aid coordination 
more broadly. They will support associated capacity development in government. The country 
focal officers should hold a bachelor's degree in a relevant field, preferably in economics, 
business administration, finance, or accounting. A master’s degree would be an advantage. The 
consultants will be expected to bring to the positions a sound understanding of ADB policies and 
processes.  Ideally,  this  understanding  would  have  been  generated  through  personal 
involvement in multilateral bank projects. The officers will participate in ADB and other training, 
seminars, and conferences that are relevant to their areas of responsibility. 
 
3.  The country focal officer for the Cook Islands will report to the regional director of the 
Pacific Subregional Office. The country focal officers for Solomon Islands and Vanuatu will 
report to the  regional  director  of the  Pacific  Liaison  and  Coordination  Office  (PLCO). The 
country focal officer for the FSM will report to the director of the Urban, Social Development, 
and Public Management Division, Pacific Department (PARD). Specific reporting procedures 
are to be established at inception. 
 
4.  The country focal officers will have several areas of responsibility: 
(i)  They will facilitate effective government engagement with ADB by (a) supporting 
government engagement with missions mobilized by ADB and facilitating the 
effective  operation  of  such  missions;  (b)  liaising  and  coordinating  with 
government,  non-state,  and  private  sectors  in  support  of  strengthened  aid 
coordination,  harmonization,  and  implementation  of  national  development 
strategies; (c) updating, collating, and analyzing information and documentation, 
as  requested,  in  support  of  promoting  a  shared  understanding  between 
government  and  ADB  as  to  development  issues  and  status;  (d)  facilitating 
communication  flows  between  government  and  ADB,  as  needed;  and 
(e) reporting and liaising with ADB on local news and other emerging information, 
particularly regarding development and economic management, and informing 
ADB of new initiatives, budget considerations, national plans, and political events. 
(ii)  They will facilitate government implementation of national development strategies 
by (a) collating, verifying, and analyzing information and documentation relating 
to  strengthened  implementation  of  national  development  strategies; (b) 
facilitating communication flows between government and ADB, as needed; (c) 
liaising and interacting with stakeholders (government, civil society, and other 
international  and  local  organizations)  in  the  implementation  of  the  national 
development strategy; (d) obtaining appropriate assistance from ADB in relation 
to  programming,  processing,  implementation,  and  monitoring  and  evaluation

activities that support implementation of the national development strategy; (e) 
supporting  government  access  to  information  on  and  engagement  in  ADB’s 
regional program as it addresses national development priorities; (f) attending 
and reporting on regional meetings or coordination events; (g) helping to identify 
and advance potential new national or regional cooperation initiatives that would 
support  the  implementation  of  national  development  strategies;  and  (h) 
supporting ADB in identifying opportunities to expand the local media coverage 
of ADB and helping formulate appropriate media messages to achieve broader 
dissemination of information of relevance to country stakeholders. 
(iii)  The  officers  will  facilitate  the  improvement  by  governments  of  their  donor 
harmonization  and  aid  coordination.  They  will  do  this  by  coordinating  with 
development partners and seeking results under a harmonization agenda. This 
will include (a) collating, verifying, and analyzing information and documentation 
relating to strengthened aid coordination and harmonization; (b) attending field-
based aid coordination and harmonization events; (c) liaising and reporting on 
information  and  coordination  activities;  (d)  pursuing  and  supporting 
harmonization and coordination between the programs of ADB and those of other 
development  partners;  (e)  facilitating  communication  between  ADB,  the 
governments, their executing agencies, and the development partner community; 
(f) reporting on the activities of the development partners; and (g) having a close 
in-country cooperative relationship with the World Bank. 
 
5.  Candidates for the country focal officer positions must meet the following requirements: 
(i)  They must be able to undertake the responsibilities detailed in paragraph 4 at a 
high level of skill and professionalism. 
(ii)  They must have at least 5 years of experience in public financial management 
professions, administration, post-evaluation, or country programming. 
(iii)  They must have excellent written and oral communication skills in English. 
(iv)  They must have experience working with government organizations and fiscal, 
economic,  and  development  assistance  management  agencies.  Past 
involvement in public relations and information dissemination and familiarity with 
Pacific cultures and institutions being advantages. 
(v)  They must have a sound understanding of ADB policies and processes. 
(vi)  They must have strong interpersonal and supervisory skills, and ability to work 
independently.  
(vii)  They must have computer skills, especially in the use of Microsoft Word and 
Excel. 
 
B.  Administrative  Assistants:  Cook  Islands  (national,  24  person-months);  the  FSM 
(national, 24 person-months); Kiribati (national, 24 person-months); Solomon Islands 
(national, 24 person-months); Vanuatu (national, 24 person-months) 
 
6.  The administrative assistants will be responsible for performing a full range of secretarial 
duties for the relevant country focal officer and coordinating activities to support implementation 
of the TA. The administrative assistants will each report to the relevant country focal officer and, 
in the case of Kiribati, to the regional director of the Pacific Subregional Office. 
 
7.  The administrative assistants will have several areas of responsibility: 
(i)  Mail, written communication, and follow-up. The administrative assistants will 
ensure that all correspondence and documents for the country focal officer are 
properly typed, prepared, and submitted on time; that all incoming mail is logged,

Appendix 3   11 
properly distributed, and brought to the attention of the country focal officer; and 
that all outgoing mail and faxes are delivered on time. 
(ii)  Oral communications and internal and external contacts. The administrative 
assistants will provide efficient reception services by properly screening incoming 
telephone  calls,  taking  accurate  messages,  and  dealing  with  queries  from 
internal and external callers to ensure they are referred in a timely manner to the 
country focal officer. 
(iii)  Calendar and travel management. The administrative assistants will ensure the 
effective coordination of the country focal officers’ schedules by maintaining their 
diaries and arranging appointments, meetings, travel, and accommodation, in 
accordance with ADB procedures. 
(iv)  Office administration. The administrative assistants will properly maintain and 
update the office filing systems and records in accordance with a framework for 
easy retrieval. They will also perform standard activities, such as maintaining 
adequate stocks of office supplies. 
(v)  Other tasks. The administrative assistants will perform other duties as may be 
reasonably required in close coordination with, and under the guidance of, the 
country focal officer. 
 
8.  The requirements for the administrative assistant positions are 
(i)  ability to undertake the responsibilities described in paragraph 7 at a high level of 
skill and professionalism; 
(ii)  at least 3 years of experience in a private or public organization; 
(iii)  good typing skills; 
(iv)  good memo composition and editing skills; 
(v)  good computer skills and familiarity with the computer systems generally used in 
multilateral organizations; 
(vi)  the  ability  to  work  with  individuals  from  different  cultural  and  national 
backgrounds; 
(vii)  good interpersonal and communication skills; 
(viii)  the ability to manage priorities and workload; and 
(ix)  the ability to work with minimum supervision and maintain composure under 
pressure. 
 
C.  Infrastructure Specialist: Solomon Islands (international, 24 person-months) 
 
9.  The infrastructure specialist will be required to assist the regional director of PLCO in 
portfolio  management,  project  administration  and  implementation,  and  project  processing 
activities in Solomon Islands, with support for operations in Nauru and Vanuatu, subject to 
available capacity. 
 
10.  The  infrastructure  specialist  will  be  stationed  in  Honiara,  Solomon  Islands.  The 
specialist’s work will cover the following broad areas:  
(i)  providing advice and technical support on loan and grant and TA implementation 
and project processing and on infrastructure development in the transport, water 
supply and sanitation, energy and telecommunication sectors to government and 
ADB; 
(ii)  recommending  best  practices  and  corrective  actions  to  provide  support  in 
addressing  implementation  issues  to  enable  the  improvement  of  portfolio 
performance in general. The specialist will assist the regional director of PLCO, 
the country team leader, and the head of the project administration unit (PAU) of

12  Appendix 3 
 
PLCO in the development and continuous improvement of policy, guidelines, and 
practices for portfolio management; 
(iii)  administering projects and TA; and 
(iv)  working within ADB’s general policies, principles, and goals with clients, visiting 
ADB missions, ADB consultants, and development partners. 
 
11.  The infrastructure specialist will have several areas of responsibility. 
 
1.  Portfolio Management 
 
12.  The infrastructure specialist will contribute to the achievement of PLCO operational key 
result areas in portfolio management by assisting the PAU head, PLCO. The key tasks will 
include  
(i)  providing  technical  backstopping  support  to  project  officers  to  resolve 
implementation issues in infrastructure sector projects; 
(ii)  providing technical support and expertise in contract management, focusing on 
Federation Internationale Des Ingenieurs-Conseils contract rules and conditions; 
(iii)  monitoring and updating the sector results framework and monitoring matrices, in 
accordance with ADB guidelines for the relevant sectors and in consultation with 
government; 
(iv)  reviewing and contributing to back-to-office reports, aide memoires, and other 
reports describing the status and performance of ongoing loan, grant, or TA 
projects; 
(v)  monitoring and analyzing project outputs and goals, including PARD’s projections 
and performance on contract awards and disbursements; 
(vi)  assisting the PAU head in preparation and conduct of country portfolio review 
and quarterly portfolio reviews; 
(vii)  assisting in review and preparation of project and TA completion reports; 
(viii)  monitoring projects classified as "at risk" in the portfolio, in consultation with the 
relevant project officer; 
(ix)  coordinating with ADB’s sector specialists for consistency of approach, exchange 
of  experiences,  continuous  improvement  of  practices,  and  integration  of 
infrastructure sector policy commitments in the management of projects; 
(x)  monitoring  changes  of  project  scope  and  implementation  arrangements, 
reallocation of loan  and grant proceeds, and changes of financing percentages; 
(xi)  leading/participating in project inception, review, midterm review, special loan 
and grant administration missions, and project completion review missions, as 
required; 
(xii)  reviewing  and  preparing  annual mission  plans for  loan, grant,  or TA  project 
administration activities; 
(xiii)  regularly following up with executing and implementing agencies on contract 
awards and disbursements to meet annual projected targets; and  
(xiv)  troubleshooting implementation and technical issues in project implementation. 
 
2.  Project Processing 
 
13.  The infrastructure specialist will collaborate with counterpart professional staff in PARD 
in  the  transport,  water  supply  and  sanitation,  energy,  and  telecommunication  sectors  in 
processing projects. Among the specialist’s key tasks will be to 
(i)  coordinate with development partners on development of TA and investment 
projects; 
(ii)  collaborate with other development partners in the transport, water supply and 
sanitation,  energy,  and  telecommunication  sectors  for  consistency  and

Appendix 3   13 
harmonization  of  approaches,  exchanges  of  experiences,  partnerships  and 
cofinancing, where appropriate; 
(iii)  assist  in  the  preparation  of  reports  and  recommendations  to  the  President, 
project administration memoranda, and other linked documents; and 
(iv)  participate in the processing of loans, grants, or TA. 
 
3.  Country Specific: Solomon Islands 
 
14.  In Solomon Islands, the infrastructure specialist will 
(i)  help the country team leader and economist prepare and review the country 
partnership strategy and country programming consultations; 
(ii)  represent ADB and other development partners on a rotational basis on the 
National Transport Fund Board; 
(iii)  support the development, update, and implementation of the National Transport 
Plan, in consultation with key government agencies and development partners; 
(iv)  coordinate  with  and  provide  help  to  the  key  government  agencies  on 
infrastructure-related environmental policies and procedures, including climate 
change adaptation; 
(v)  develop ADB’s project portfolio in the transport, water supply and sanitation, 
energy,  and  telecommunication  sectors,  in  consultation  with  key government 
agencies and development partners; 
(vi)  support  ADB  mission  leaders  in  designing,  formulating,  and  processing 
infrastructure loans, grants, or TA; 
(vii)  coordinate with ADB’s development coordinator and development partners and 
organize infrastructure meetings to discuss the performance of all donor-funded 
projects; and 
(viii)  provide input and updated information related to infrastructure for the country 
performance assessments, as well as related fact sheets and briefings to the 
regional director of PLCO. 
 
4.  Knowledge Sharing 
 
15.  The infrastructure specialist will participate in and contribute to relevant internal and 
external  training  and  conferences  and  other  activities  for  advocacy,  dissemination,  and 
knowledge building. 
 
5.  Supervision and Development 
 
16.  The infrastructure specialist will 
(i)  take on the role of project team leader and supervise the work of team members;  
(ii)  assist  counterpart  agency  staff  in  supervision  and  training  on  project-related 
procedures, where required; and  
(iii)  troubleshoot technical issues on site and provide advisory assistance to  the 
counterpart agency staff or project management unit on related issues. 
 
17.  The requirements for the infrastructure specialist position are 
(i)  a university degree in engineering, preferably at the postgraduate level or its 
equivalent, with a background in transport, project management, or other related 
fields;  
(ii)  ability to undertake the responsibilities mentioned in paragraph. 16 at a high level 
of skill and professionalism; and 
(iii)  at least 10 years of experience in either portfolio management or overall project 
or program administration and coordination, or both.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  AusAID  –  Australian Agency for International Development 
DCO  –  development coordination office 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
FSM  –  Federated States of Micronesia 
PARD  –  Pacific Department 
PAU  –  project administration unit 
PLCO    Pacific Liaison and Coordination Office 
SPSO  –  Pacific Subregional Office 
TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional–Capacity development technical assistance (R-CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Public  sector  management  (economic  management  and 
management of public affairs, public administration, road transport, 
urban  transport,  information  and  communication  technology, 
renewable energy, energy efficiency and conservation, water supply 
and sanitation) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Governance  (economic  and  financial  governance,  public 
administration  [national,  decentralized,  and  regional]);  economic 
growth  (promoting  economic  efficiency  and  enabling  business 
environment); social development (human development); capacity 
development  (institutional  development;  organizational 
development;  client  relations,  network,  and  partnership 
development)  
Location (impact)  –  Rural (medium), urban (high), national (high) 
Partnership  –  Government of Australia, World Bank  
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars.
